sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated October 4, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden urges Schenker to press Brahms [for material on Bülow]; he thinks that d’Albert will benefit from Schenker’s article about him in Die Zukunft; he reports cordial impressions of Humperdinck from Cosima and Siegfried Wagner; and he asks whether an article he wrote was any good.

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated October 4, 1894

tei:transcription.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] Deutsche Reichspost Postkarte
An [/] Herrn Dr. H. Schenker in Wien Wohnung III Fraungasse 1

mit Allem einverstanden. Bitte, drängen Sie Brahms!! Harden has been using Schenker as a go-between to try to persuade Brahms to write something for Die Zukunft in support of a proposed monument for Hans von Bülow. See OJ 11/42, [14], May 11, 1894. Ich glaube, d’Albert Click on Eugen d'Albert. wird Vortheil haben.
Besten Gruß Ihnen u. Gelber, Probably the scholar of German language and literature, Adolph Gelber (1856-1923).
dem Bösen[,] von Ihrem erg. versetzten [signed:] H. 4/10 94

[postscripts:] Wagners, Mutter u. Sohn <strike>waren</strike> sprachen mir sehr warm von Humperdinck. The German composer Engelbert Humperdinck (1854–1921), who assisted Wagner in preparing the first performance of Parsifal in 1881–82 at Bayreuth, and who was private music tutor to Wagner's son, Siegfried in 1889–90. (NGDM)
Mein „Parsifal“ war wohl dummes Zeug? The reference is presumably to an unidentified publication of Harden’s.

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated October 4, 1894

tei:translation.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] German Imperial Post Postcard
To Dr. H. Schenker in Vienna Address III Fraungasse 1
Agreed on everything. Please, press Brahms!! I think d’Albert will benefit.
Best regards to you and the misbehaved Gelber, from
Yours truly and stood-up, [signed:] H. October 4, 1894
The Wagners, mother and son, spoke very cordially to me about Humperdinck.
